authorization-boundary.description:
The services and capabilities provided by Adobe Managed Services (AMS) on AWS and Azure which enables the provisioning and management of Adobe Experience Manager (AEM) customer topologies as a platform. This includes all ancillary services deployed by AMS on AWS to ensure effective and efficient management of AEM implementations for customers, collectively referred to as the Management & Monitoring Environment (M2 Environment).

All customisation, assets curation, and integration performed by the customer on their own topologies to create a tailored solution (by customers) are excluded from this authorisation boundary. Only the vanilla customer topologies delivered by AMS are included within this authorisation boundary.

system-implementation.description:
AEM Gov Cloud Australia Hosted at AWS by Adobe Managed Services

Cloud Service Providers: IaaS: AWS, Azure, PaaS: Not Applicable, SaaS: Okta, Trend Micro

implemented-requirements.description: The Board of Directors and the Chief Security Officer (appointed by the Board) are responsible for ensuring that appropriate measures are in place to maintain cybersecurity across the organisation. This includes securing Adobe’s products and services offered to customers, as well as internal services created to support staff and enhance the customer experience.

implemented-requirements.description: In AMS, all security risks across supply chains, infrastructure, operating systems, applications and data are identified, documented and formally accepted by Mitch Nelson before any product or service is authorised for customer use. This ensures risks are acknowledged upfront and compliance obligations are met. Once in operation, systems are continuously monitored through vulnerability management, supply chain assurance and operational security processes. Any new or changed risks are reassessed at lifecycle events, with updated acceptance recorded to maintain audit-defensible traceability and customer assurance. Identified risks are also socialised with the TechGRC team, who analyse them against the broader Adobe Risk Matrix and escalate to Adobe Senior Leadership if deemed necessary.

implemented-requirements.description: In AMS, the business criticality of systems — including cyber supply chains, infrastructure, operating systems, applications and data — is formally assessed during the design and onboarding phases. Each system is classified against defined criteria such as customer impact, compliance obligations, and operational dependencies. The outcomes of these assessments are documented in AMS governance records, ensuring traceability and providing a defensible basis for prioritisation, risk management, and escalation to senior leadership where required.

implemented-requirements.description: In AMS, the confidentiality, integrity and availability (CIA) requirements for systems — including cyber supply chains, infrastructure, operating systems, applications and data — are formally assessed during the design and onboarding phases. Each requirement is determined against business criticality, compliance obligations and customer impact, then documented in AMS governance records. This ensures that security expectations are traceable, defensible and consistently applied throughout the operational lifecycle.

implemented-requirements.description: In AMS, all security risks across cyber supply chains, infrastructure, operating systems, applications and data are systematically identified and documented. Each risk is assessed against compliance and business impact criteria, with risk management decisions — such as mitigation, acceptance or escalation — formally recorded. This ensures transparency for customers, provides audit‑defensible accountability, and demonstrates that AMS maintains a structured and proactive approach to risk management throughout the system lifecycle.

implemented-requirements.description: In AMS, all systems — including infrastructure, operating systems and applications — are managed across their full lifecycle in alignment with business criticality and confidentiality, integrity and availability (CIA) requirements. Each stage, from planning and design through to development, testing, deployment, maintenance and eventual decommissioning, is governed by documented processes that ensure risks are addressed, compliance obligations are met and customer impact is minimised. This structured approach provides audit‑defensible assurance that systems remain secure, reliable and fit for purpose throughout their operational life.

implemented-requirements.description: In AMS, only the solutions that are implemented, developed or customised by AMS follow the principles of Secure by Design and Secure by Default. AMS does not enforce these principles on components, integrations or products that are not developed by AMS, though such elements are still subject to broader compliance and risk management processes.

implemented-requirements.description: In AMS, all systems — including infrastructure, operating systems, applications and data — are delivered and supported exclusively by trusted suppliers who have been vetted against Adobe’s corporate security, compliance and procurement standards. Supplier relationships are subject to ongoing assurance processes, ensuring that only approved vendors with demonstrable capability and integrity provide services. The suppliers and third‑party details are maintained in Graphite Connect, providing traceability and transparency for stakeholders. This approach gives confidence that AMS systems are supported by reliable partners and remain aligned with compliance and risk management expectations throughout their lifecycle.

implemented-requirements.description: In AMS, systems — including infrastructure, operating systems and applications — are configured to minimise their attack surface. Specifically, SSA implementations and management components are highly restricted, with access limited only to authorised Adobe staff. Such access requires formal authorisation and VPN connectivity, ensuring that only trusted personnel can interact with the management components that orchestrate customer topologies. This layered restriction significantly reduces exposure and strengthens overall security posture.

implemented-requirements.description: Access to administrative functions is restricted to authorised Adobe staff, enforced through VPN connectivity, role‑based controls and audit logging. props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:
When malicious code is detected, the following steps are taken to handle the infection:

- the infected systems are isolated
- all previously connected media used in the period leading up to the infection are scanned for signs of infection and isolated if necessary
- antivirus applications are used to remove the infection from infected systems and media
- if the infection cannot be reliably removed, systems are restored from a known good backup or rebuilt.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:
Systems have a cybersecurity incident response plan that covers the following:

- guidelines on what constitutes a cybersecurity incident
- the types of cybersecurity incidents likely to be encountered and the expected response to each type
- how to report cybersecurity incidents, internally to an organisation and externally to relevant authorities
- other parties which need to be informed in the event of a cybersecurity incident
- the authority, or authorities, responsible for investigating and responding to cybersecurity incidents
- the criteria by which an investigation of a cybersecurity incident would be requested from a law enforcement agency, the Australian Signals Directorate or other relevant authority
- the steps necessary to ensure the integrity of evidence relating to a cybersecurity incident
- system contingency measures or a reference to such details if they are located in a separate document.

- the steps necessary to ensure the integrity of evidence relating to a cybersecurity incident
- system contingency measures or a reference to such details if they are located in a separate document.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:

- the establishment and maintenance of authorised baseline configurations for systems

- who needs to be consulted prior to routine and urgent changes to the configuration of systems
- who needs to approve routine and urgent changes to the configuration of systems
- who needs to be notified of routine and urgent changes to the configuration of systems
- what additional change management and configuration management processes and procedures need to be followed before, during and after routine and urgent changes to the configuration of systems.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:
Personnel are advised to take the following precautions when using mobile devices:

- never leave mobile devices or removable media unattended, including by placing them in checked-in luggage or leaving them in hotel safes
- never store credentials with mobile devices that they grant access to, such as in laptop computer bags
- never lend mobile devices or removable media to untrusted people, even if briefly
- never allow untrusted people to connect their mobile devices or removable media to your mobile devices, including for charging
- never connect mobile devices to designated charging stations or wall outlet charging ports
- never use gifted or unauthorised peripherals, chargers or removable media with mobile devices
- never use removable media for data transfers or backups that have not been checked for malicious code beforehand
- avoid reuse of removable media once used with other parties’ systems or mobile devices
- avoid connecting mobile devices to open or untrusted Wi-Fi networks
- consider disabling any communications capabilities of mobile devices when not in use, such as Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, Near Field Communication and ultra-wideband
- consider periodically rebooting mobile devices
- consider using a VPN connection to encrypt all cellular and wireless communications
- consider using encrypted email or messaging apps for all communications.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:
If travelling overseas with mobile devices to high or extreme risk countries, personnel are:

- issued with newly provisioned user accounts, mobile devices and removable media from a pool of dedicated travel devices which are used solely for work-related activities
- advised on how to apply and inspect tamper seals to key areas of mobile devices
- advised to avoid taking any personal mobile devices, especially if rooted or jailbroken.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
If travelling overseas with mobile devices to high or extreme risk countries, personnel are:

- issued with newly provisioned user accounts, mobile devices and removable media from a pool of dedicated travel devices which are used solely for work-related activities
- advised on how to apply and inspect tamper seals to key areas of mobile devices
- advised to avoid taking any personal mobile devices, especially if rooted or jailbroken.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:
Before travelling overseas with mobile devices, personnel take the following actions:

- record all details of the mobile devices being taken, such as product types, serial numbers and International Mobile Equipment Identity numbers
- update all operating systems and applications
- remove all non-essential data, applications and user accounts
- backup all remaining data, applications and settings.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Before travelling overseas with mobile devices, personnel take the following actions:

- record all details of the mobile devices being taken, such as product types, serial numbers and International Mobile Equipment Identity numbers
- update all operating systems and applications
- remove all non-essential data, applications and user accounts
- backup all remaining data, applications and settings.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:
Personnel report the potential compromise of mobile devices, removable media or credentials to their organisation as soon as possible, especially if they:

- provide credentials to foreign government officials
- decrypt mobile devices for foreign government officials
- have mobile devices taken out of sight by foreign government officials
- have mobile devices or removable media stolen, including if later returned
- lose mobile devices or removable media, including if later found
- observe unusual behaviour of mobile devices.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Personnel report the potential compromise of mobile devices, removable media or credentials to their organisation as soon as possible, especially if they:

- provide credentials to foreign government officials
- decrypt mobile devices for foreign government officials
- have mobile devices taken out of sight by foreign government officials
- have mobile devices or removable media stolen, including if later returned
- lose mobile devices or removable media, including if later found
- observe unusual behaviour of mobile devices.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:
Upon returning from travelling overseas with mobile devices, personnel take the following actions:

- sanitise and reset mobile devices, including all removable media
- decommission any credentials that left their possession during their travel
- report if significant doubt exists as to the integrity of any mobile devices or removable media.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Upon returning from travelling overseas with mobile devices, personnel take the following actions:

- sanitise and reset mobile devices, including all removable media
- decommission any credentials that left their possession during their travel
- report if significant doubt exists as to the integrity of any mobile devices or removable media.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:
If returning from travelling overseas with mobile devices to high or extreme risk countries, personnel take the following additional actions:

- reset credentials used with mobile devices, including those used for remote access to their organisation’s systems
- monitor user accounts for any indicators of compromise, such as failed logon attempts.

parts.name: statement

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:

- denies users the ability to disable the screen locking mechanism.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:
Denial-of-service attack mitigation strategies are discussed with cloud service providers, specifically:

- their capacity to withstand denial-of-service attacks
- costs likely to be incurred as a result of denial-of-service attacks
- availability monitoring and thresholds for notification of denial-of-service attacks
- thresholds for turning off any online services or functionality during denial-of-service attacks
- pre-approved actions that can be undertaken during denial-of-service attacks
- any arrangements with upstream service providers to block malicious network traffic as far upstream as possible.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:
Denial-of-service attack mitigation strategies are discussed with cloud service providers, specifically:

- their capacity to withstand denial-of-service attacks
- costs likely to be incurred as a result of denial-of-service attacks
- availability monitoring and thresholds for notification of denial-of-service attacks
- thresholds for turning off any online services or functionality during denial-of-service attacks
- pre-approved actions that can be undertaken during denial-of-service attacks
- any arrangements with upstream service providers to block malicious network traffic as far upstream as possible.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value:
The SSH daemon is configured to:

- only listen on the required interfaces (ListenAddress xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx)
- have a suitable login banner (Banner x)
- have a login authentication timeout of no more than 60 seconds (LoginGraceTime 60)
- disable host-based authentication (HostbasedAuthentication no)
- disable rhosts-based authentication (IgnoreRhosts yes)
- disable the ability to login directly as root (PermitRootLogin no)
- disable empty passwords (PermitEmptyPasswords no)
- disable connection forwarding (AllowTCPForwarding no)
- disable gateway ports (GatewayPorts no)
- disable X11 forwarding (X11Forwarding no).

parts.name: statement
parts.prose:

- disable empty passwords (PermitEmptyPasswords no)

implemented-requirements.description: AMS does not deliver the Gateway and CDS solutions to it's customers. However, AEM content management solution data store is indexed on file hashes due to which by default solution ensures the integrity of hosted file is not compromised.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value: Files imported or exported via gateways or CDSs that have a digital signature or cryptographic checksum are validated.

parts.name: statement
parts.prose: Files imported or exported via gateways or CDSs that have a digital signature or cryptographic checksum are validated.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value: Evaluated peripheral switches are used when sharing peripherals between systems.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value: Data transfer processes, and supporting data transfer procedures, are developed, implemented and maintained.

props.name: catalog-control-description
props.value: When manually importing data to systems, the data is scanned for malicious and active content.
